commit_message:
Object: Make object target version check sorted

This patch just does cleanup work in object's obj_make_compatible().
We keep all target version check sorted, this will have a good readable.

Besides make compatible for pci_device object 1.3.

Change-Id: Ie20123a68d9fa25c5f710f9798fa491e4f99926d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/00/269500/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if target_version < (1, 6): bus = primitive.get('hw_disk_bus', None) if bus in ('lxc', 'uml'): raise exception.ObjectActionError( action='obj_make_compatible', reason='hw_disk_bus=%s not supported in version %s' % ( bus, target_version))
deleted_lines: if target_version < (1, 6): bus = primitive.get('hw_disk_bus', None) if bus in ('lxc', 'uml'): raise exception.ObjectActionError( action='obj_make_compatible', reason='hw_disk_bus=%s not supported in version %s' % ( bus, target_version))

subject: Fix nova-compute service start order
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-27 16:57:56.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/5066b6d9fc924641a8c8169d773b75ccfefca26e', 'message': 'Fix nova-compute service start order

    After rebooting all nodes in the cluster, all the instances that were
    running on the cluster are stuck in Status ACTIVE, Task state:
    powering-off, Power state: Crashed.

    The manager.init_host method is the one that tries to shut off the
    instances which are in state active but not running. it does so
    by RPC. But the starting of the RPC server is only done in the
    server.start method, which is called after the init_host is called.
    The RPC message never gets back to nova-compute.

    Moving the cleanup of the instances state to the post_start_hook
    function, fixes this problem.

    Change-Id: Ia01b0f63e4bc8d6b34f00346675d7f208fe805ce
    Closes-Bug: 1593186

Change-Id: I04f52582fd10bdd696189c7b2e148530f5eeb7e9

    function, fixes this problem.

commit_message:
Fix nova-compute service start order

    After rebooting all nodes in the cluster, all the instances that were
    running on the cluster are stuck in Status ACTIVE, Task state:
    powering-off, Power state: Crashed.

    The manager.init_host method is the one that tries to shut off the
    instances which are in state active but not running. it does so
    by RPC. But the starting of the RPC server is only done in the
    server.start method, which is called after the init_host is called.
    The RPC message never gets back to nova-compute.

    Moving the cleanup of the instances state to the post_start_hook
    function, fixes this problem.

    Change-Id: Ia01b0f63e4bc8d6b34f00346675d7f208fe805ce
    Closes-Bug: 1593186

Change-Id: I04f52582fd10bdd696189c7b2e148530f5eeb7e9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/66/334566/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def post_start_hook(self): """After the RPC server was initialized, update instances in the current node. """ context = nova.context.get_admin_context() instances = objects.InstanceList.get_by_host( context, self.host, expected_attrs=['info_cache', 'metadata']) try: # checking that instance was not already evacuated to other host self._destroy_evacuated_instances(context) for instance in instances: self._init_instance(context, instance) finally: if CONF.defer_iptables_apply: self.driver.filter_defer_apply_off() self._update_scheduler_instance_info(context, instances)
deleted_lines: context = nova.context.get_admin_context() instances = objects.InstanceList.get_by_host( context, self.host, expected_attrs=['info_cache', 'metadata']) try: # checking that instance was not already evacuated to other host self._destroy_evacuated_instances(context) for instance in instances: self._init_instance(context, instance) finally: if CONF.defer_iptables_apply: self.driver.filter_defer_apply_off() self._update_scheduler_instance_info(context, instances)

commit_message:
[WIP] Change rescude response code

Change rescue controller response code to 202
as far as that method is asyncronous.

deleted_lines: # TODO(cyeoh): Should be responding here with 202 Accept # because rescue is an async call, but keep to 200 # for backwards compatibility reasons.

While debugging a Tempest race failure it would have
been useful to see when the ports on an instance were
deallocated, especially knowing which ports are unbound
versus which ports are deleted.

This simply adds debug logging of the ports in both
situations.

Change-Id: Idde18acc04967bfe73c3e869e36341ddfbbbb011

commit_message:
Add debug logging when deallocating ports

While debugging a Tempest race failure it would have
been useful to see when the ports on an instance were
deallocated, especially knowing which ports are unbound
versus which ports are deleted.

This simply adds debug logging of the ports in both
situations.

The unit tests are updated for the conditional checks
that were put into the code - which should have probably
been this way to begin with.

Change-Id: Idde18acc04967bfe73c3e869e36341ddfbbbb011
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/73/328673/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Scheduler use Claim to check resource consumption
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-01-02 05:19:44.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/6933a42205dddc22bc98f1d304355d04fb43abd7', 'message': 'Scheduler use Claim to check resource consumption

This patch implements a new class `Claim` to check resource consumption
in host states. This patch encapsulates previous claim logics into the
new Claim inherited from `nova.compute.claims.Claim`. Also, previously
implemented claim tests are moved from test_host_manager.py to
test_claims.py to make sure there are no regressions in scheduler.

Note it seems like there are still many duplications because this patch
only touches scheduler code. This makes sure that scheduler can safely
use Claim without touching any code in `nova.compute.claims.Claim`. This
makes life easier in finally remove duplications in the next patch.

Change-Id: Iad6e447072f15ba8b71f35342ee959f677fbdbff
Partially-Implements: bp host-state-level-locking
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-01-06 06:59:01.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/d03b3dafd7af8e3c22a1e62d5249463fabc630cb', 'message': 'Scheduler use Claim to check resource consumption

This patch implements a new class `Claim` to check resource consumption
in host states, including cpu, ram, disk, numa topology and pci. This
patch encapsulates claim logics into the new Claim inherited from
`nova.compute.claims.Claim`. Also, claim tests are implemented in
test_claims.py to make sure there are no regressions in scheduler.

This patch also ensures that no resources are consumed in the host
state if any of the claims in `HostState.consume_from_request()` fails,
and the scheduler will change to try the second best host. This process
is identical to the claim logic in the compute nodes, so that some host
failing conditions in the compute nodes can be detected as soon as
possible to prevent some expensive retries. Related tests are also
added.

Note it seems like there are still many duplications because this patch
only touches scheduler code. This makes sure that scheduler can safely
use Claim without touching any code in `nova.compute.claims.Claim`. This
makes life easier in finally remove duplications in the next patch.

Change-Id: Iad6e447072f15ba8b71f35342ee959f677fbdbff
Partially-Implements: bp host-state-level-locking

commit_message:
Scheduler use Claim to check resource consumption

This patch implements a new class `Claim` to check resource consumption
in host states, including cpu, ram, disk, numa topology and pci. This
patch encapsulates claim logics into the new Claim inherited from
`nova.compute.claims.Claim`. Also, claim tests are implemented in
test_claims.py to make sure there are no regressions in scheduler.

This patch also ensures that no resources are consumed in the host
state if any of the claims in `HostState.consume_from_request()` fails,
and the scheduler will change to try the second best host. This process
is identical to the claim logic in the compute nodes, so that some host
failing conditions in the compute nodes can be detected as soon as
possible to prevent some expensive retries. Related tests are also
added.

Note `set_update_time_on_success` decorator is removed because the
exception handling is duplicated in `FilterScheduler._select_host()` and
the time update logic is implemented in
`HostState.consume_from_request()` in only 2 lines.

Note test_host_manager.HostStateTestCase.\
test_stat_consumption_from_instance_with_pci_exception is replaced by
test_claims.ClaimTestCase.test_claim_pci_fails because the consumption
will be checked firstly by claims in `host.consume_from_request`.

Change-Id: Iad6e447072f15ba8b71f35342ee959f677fbdbff
Partially-Implements: bp host-state-level-locking
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/38/262938/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2016 OpenStack Foundation # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """ Claim objects for use with scheduler resource consumption. """ from oslo_log import log as logging from nova.compute import claims from nova import exception from nova.i18n import _ from nova.i18n import _LI from nova.virt import hardware LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) class Claim(claims.Claim): """A declaration that a host state operation will require free resources. Claims serve as marker objects that resources are being checked before the consume_from_request process runs to do a full reconciliation of resource usage. """ def __init__(self, spec_obj, host_state, limits=None): # Stash a copy of the request at the current point of time self.spec_obj = spec_obj.obj_clone() self.host_state = host_state self.instance_cells = None self.claimed_numa_topology = None # Check claim at constructor to avoid mess code # Raise exception ComputeResourcesUnavailable if claim failed self._claim_test(self.host_state, limits) @property def disk_gb(self): return self.spec_obj.root_gb + self.spec_obj.ephemeral_gb @property def memory_mb(self): return self.spec_obj.memory_mb @property def vcpus(self): return self.spec_obj.vcpus @property def numa_topology(self): return self.spec_obj.numa_topology @property def pci_requests(self): pci_requests = self.spec_obj.pci_requests if pci_requests and self.host_state.pci_stats: pci_requests = pci_requests.requests else: pci_requests = None return pci_requests def abort(self): raise NotImplemented("There is no need to abort a claim in" " host state.") def _claim_test(self, resources, limits=None): """Test if this claim can be satisfied given available resources and optional oversubscription limits This should be called before the compute node actually consumes the resources required to execute the claim. :param resources: available local host state resources :returns: Return true if resources are available to claim. """ if not limits: limits = {} # If an individual limit is None, the resource will be considered # unlimited: memory_mb_limit = limits.get('memory_mb') disk_gb_limit = limits.get('disk_gb') vcpus_limit = limits.get('vcpu') numa_topology_limit = limits.get('numa_topology') LOG.info(_LI("Attempting claim: memory %(memory_mb)d MB, " "disk %(disk_gb)d GB, vcpus %(vcpus)d CPU"), {'memory_mb': self.memory_mb, 'disk_gb': self.disk_gb, 'vcpus': self.vcpus}) reasons = [self._test_memory(resources, memory_mb_limit), self._test_disk(resources, disk_gb_limit), self._test_vcpus(resources, vcpus_limit), self._test_numa_topology(resources, numa_topology_limit), self._test_pci()] reasons = reasons + self._test_ext_resources(limits) reasons = [r for r in reasons if r is not None] if len(reasons) > 0: raise exception.ComputeResourcesUnavailable(reason= "; ".join(reasons)) LOG.info(_LI('Claim successful')) def _test_memory(self, resources, limit): type_ = _("memory") unit = "MB" total = resources.total_usable_ram_mb used = resources.total_usable_ram_mb - resources.free_ram_mb requested = self.memory_mb return self._test(type_, unit, total, used, requested, limit) def _test_disk(self, resources, limit): type_ = _("disk") unit = "GB" total = resources.total_usable_disk_gb used = resources.total_usable_disk_gb - resources.free_disk_mb / 1024 requested = self.disk_gb return self._test(type_, unit, total, used, requested, limit) def _test_vcpus(self, resources, limit): type_ = _("vcpu") unit = "VCPU" total = resources.vcpus_total used = resources.vcpus_used requested = self.vcpus return self._test(type_, unit, total, used, requested, limit) def _test_pci(self): pci_requests = self.pci_requests claimed_numa_topology = self.claimed_numa_topology if claimed_numa_topology: self.instance_cells = claimed_numa_topology.cells if pci_requests: if not self.host_state.pci_stats.support_requests( pci_requests, self.instance_cells): return _('Claim pci failed.') def _test_ext_resources(self, limits): return [] def _test_numa_topology(self, resources, limit): host_topology, _fmt = hardware.host_topology_and_format_from_host( self.host_state) requested_topology = self.numa_topology pci_requests = self.pci_requests if host_topology and requested_topology: pci_stats = None if pci_requests: pci_stats = self.host_state.pci_stats self.claimed_numa_topology = ( hardware.numa_fit_instance_to_host( host_topology, requested_topology, limits=limit, pci_requests=pci_requests, pci_stats=pci_stats)) if not self.claimed_numa_topology: if pci_requests: return (_("Requested instance NUMA topology together with" " requested PCI devices cannot fit the given" " host NUMA topology")) else: return (_("Requested instance NUMA topology cannot fit " "the given host NUMA topology")) def _test(self, type_, unit, total, used, requested, limit): """Test if the given type of resource needed for a claim can be safely allocated. """ LOG.info(_LI('Total %(type)s: %(total)d %(unit)s, used: %(used).02f ' '%(unit)s'), {'type': type_, 'total': total, 'unit': unit, 'used': used}) if limit is None: # treat resource as unlimited: LOG.info(_LI('%(type)s limit not specified, defaulting to ' 'unlimited'), {'type': type_}) return free = limit - used # Oversubscribed resource policy info: LOG.info(_LI('%(type)s limit: %(limit).02f %(unit)s, ' 'free: %(free).02f %(unit)s'), {'type': type_, 'limit': limit, 'free': free, 'unit': unit}) if requested > free: return (_('Free %(type)s %(free).02f ' '%(unit)s < requested %(requested)d %(unit)s') % {'type': type_, 'free': free, 'unit': unit, 'requested': requested})

commit_message:
Query procceeding status migration in confirm/revert_resize()

This patch adds proceeding status while query migration objects while
doing confirm/revert resize, by doing this we can re-issue this
confirm/revert operation in case of rpc message is missed after casting
to compute node.

Closes-bug: #1536703
Change-Id: I38b7585dcae39cfab15481c369950d626cc88727

subject: Improve scheduler host state's update model
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-12-28 08:04:20.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/931f337796816bad2f3ab1d7d534177356bf05dc', 'message': "Improve scheduler host state's update model

Current update model of scheduler host state has some issues. First, a
host state cache will be updated even if it is already the same with the
latest db data(i.e. HostState.db_updated = compute.updated_at =
HostState.db_updated). Second, the cache won't be updated even if db
data is newer in a specific case(i.e. HostState.db_updated <
compute.updated_at < HostState.updated).

This patch adds a timestamp to record when a host state cache is updated
by db(HostState.db_updated), and fixes the first issue. This complete
update model covers all 6 possible conditions:
1. compute_db_updated < cache_db_updated/cache_updated   -> return
2. cache_db_updated = cache_updated = compute_db_updated -> return
3. cache_db_updated = compute_db_updated < cache_updated -> return
4. cache_db_updated < compute_db_updated < cache_updated -> return
5. cache_db_updated < compute_db_updated = cache_updated -> update
6. cache_db_updated/cache_updated < compute_db_updated   -> update

However, this patch won't fix the second issue by setting #4 to
'-> update' because it will introduce much more unexpected retries due
to the losses of recent consumptions when refresh the host state,
causing a worse impact from the bug #1341420. A detailed analysis can
be found at https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1341420/comments/24

So the second issue is left unsolved because this leads to less
consumption losses and thus can reduce retries to minimum in
'one scheduler instance per cell' scenario. It should be solved after
consumptions are instantiated by claims during host state consumption,
which will be implemented in bp host-state-level-locking.

Change-Id: I5ecbab9497d94c9e935c618ccbffb60f6019a104
Partial-Bug: #1341420

commit_message:
Improve scheduler host state's update model

Current update model of scheduler host state has some issues. First, a
host state cache will be updated even if it is already the same with the
latest db data(i.e. HostState.db_updated = compute.updated_at =
HostState.db_updated). Second, the cache won't be updated even if db
data is newer in a specific case(i.e. HostState.db_updated <
compute.updated_at < HostState.updated).

This patch adds a timestamp to record when a host state cache is updated
by db(HostState.db_updated), and fixes the first issue. This complete
update model covers all 6 possible conditions:
1. compute_db_updated < cache_db_updated/cache_updated   -> return
2. cache_db_updated = cache_updated = compute_db_updated -> return
3. cache_db_updated = compute_db_updated < cache_updated -> return
4. cache_db_updated < compute_db_updated < cache_updated -> return
5. cache_db_updated < compute_db_updated = cache_updated -> update
6. cache_db_updated/cache_updated < compute_db_updated   -> update

However, this patch won't fix the second issue by setting #4 to
'-> update' because it will introduce much more unexpected retries due
to the losses of recent consumptions when refresh the host state,
causing a worse impact from the bug #1341420. A detailed analysis can
be found at https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1341420/comments/24

So the second issue is left unsolved because this leads to less
consumption losses and thus can reduce retries to minimum in
'one scheduler instance per cell' scenario. It should be solved after
consumptions are instantiated by claims during host state consumption,
which will be implemented in bp host-state-level-locking.

This patch also applies to IronicNodeState.

Change-Id: I5ecbab9497d94c9e935c618ccbffb60f6019a104
Partial-Bug: #1341420
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/20/261920/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.db_updated = None cache_db_updated = self.db_updated cache_updated = self.updated compute_db_updated = compute.updated_at # There are 6 possibilities to decide whether to update host state: # 1. compute_db_updated < cache_db_updated/cache_updated -> return # 2. cache_db_updated = cache_updated = compute_db_updated -> return # 3. cache_db_updated = compute_db_updated < cache_updated -> return # 4. cache_db_updated < compute_db_updated < cache_updated -> return # 5. cache_db_updated < compute_db_updated = cache_updated -> update # 6. cache_db_updated/cache_updated < compute_db_updated -> update # # This update model fits best when there is only one scheduler instance # because the cache won't be updated in the #4 case. if (cache_updated and compute_db_updated): if (cache_updated > compute_db_updated): return elif (cache_db_updated and cache_db_updated == cache_updated and cache_updated == compute_db_updated): return self.db_updated = compute.updated_at
deleted_lines: if (self.updated and compute.updated_at and self.updated > compute.updated_at): return

commit_message:
VMware: add support for VVOL datastores

Similarly to VSAN, only streamOptimized images can be provisioned on
VVOL datastores.

blueprint vmware-vvol-support

Change-Id: I021e2021c128da4db2f53a9973658a92a937bfbf

commit_message:
Make LM downtime params mutable

* libvirt.live_migration_downtime
* libvirt.live_migration_downtime_steps
* libvirt.live_migration_downtime_delay

These will immediately apply to all running live migrations.

The old code precomputed the downtime steps. Since the downtime params
are now mutable, this no longer makes sense and would lead to
convoluted code. Now we compute the next downtime on the fly.

I updated the values in the example to match the values the tests run
with (by default).

Part of bp:mutable-config-ocata

Change-Id: I379aeddf0e141a1ceccb8d107a87d35e5f8de823

added_lines: @mock.patch.object(fakelibvirt.virDomain, "migrateSetMaxDowntime") @mock.patch.object(libvirt_driver.LibvirtDriver, "_migration_downtime_steps") def test_live_migration_monitor_downtime_mutate( self, mock_downtime_steps, mock_set_downtime): self.flags(live_migration_completion_timeout=1000000, live_migration_progress_timeout=1000000, group='libvirt') # We've setup 4 fake downtime steps - first value is the # time delay, second is the downtime value downtime_steps = [ (90, 10), (180, 50), (270, 200), (500, 300), ] mock_downtime_steps.return_value = downtime_steps # Each one of these fake times is used for time.time() # when a new domain_info_records entry is consumed. # Times are chosen so that only the first 3 downtime # steps are needed. fake_times = [0, 1, 30, 95, 150, 200, 300] # A normal sequence where see all the normal job states domain_info_records = [ host.DomainJobInfo( type=fakelibvirt.VIR_DOMAIN_JOB_NONE), host.DomainJobInfo( type=fakelibvirt.VIR_DOMAIN_JOB_UNBOUNDED), host.DomainJobInfo( type=fakelibvirt.VIR_DOMAIN_JOB_UNBOUNDED), host.DomainJobInfo( type=fakelibvirt.VIR_DOMAIN_JOB_UNBOUNDED), host.DomainJobInfo( type=fakelibvirt.VIR_DOMAIN_JOB_UNBOUNDED), host.DomainJobInfo( type=fakelibvirt.VIR_DOMAIN_JOB_UNBOUNDED), "thread-finish", "domain-stop", host.DomainJobInfo( type=fakelibvirt.VIR_DOMAIN_JOB_COMPLETED), ] def set_downtime(value): if mock_set_downtime.call_count == 1: mock_downtime_steps.return_value = [ (120, 30), (240, 100), (500, 300), ] # Fake value just to trigger the mutation handling code CONF.libvirt.live_migration_downtime = 11 mock_set_downtime.side_effect = set_downtime self._test_live_migration_monitoring(domain_info_records, fake_times, self.EXPECT_SUCCESS) mock_set_downtime.assert_has_calls([mock.call(10), mock.call(30), mock.call(100)])

the code path is nova/compute/manager/_do_build_and_run_instance:

    VM creation failed for any reason that throws RescheduledException
    retry is not null on the first attempt
    deallocate_networks_on_reschedule returns False
    network_api.cleanup_instance_network_on_host does nothing
        (e.g. in neutronv2/api)

The side effect of not proper cleaning up the network is that VM would
be rescheduled to a different hypervisor with in-compatible network and
messing up all VMs on that hypervisor.

Fix is to revise the network_api.cleanup_instance_network_on_host to
resturn a boolean flag to indicate the cleanup's success. If the
network_api.cleanup_instance_network_on_host is done successfully, then
call _cleanup_allocated_networks

the code path is nova/compute/manager/_do_build_and_run_instance:

    1. VM creation failed for any reason that throws RescheduledException
    2. retry is not null on the first attempt
    3. deallocate_networks_on_reschedule returns False
    4. network_api.cleanup_instance_network_on_host does nothing
      (e.g, neutronv2/api currently has a null implemnetation)

The side effect of not proper cleaning up the network is that VM would
be rescheduled to a different hypervisor with in-compatible network, causing
the VM lose connectivity

Part of the trigger for the issue is that the bridged_network is not compatible
among the candidate compute nodes on retry. The current proposed fix is to
detect the presence of immobile networks (bridge_network in this case), and if
true, call _cleanup_allocated_networks.

closes-bug: #1597596

Change-Id: Ida5a48d0e8612af639e6f4ce9fe590c798f4de51
Signed-off-by: aihuaedwardli <aihuaedwardli@yahoo.com>

commit_message:
Fix code path when network is not cleaned up

the code path is nova/compute/manager/_do_build_and_run_instance:

    1. VM creation failed for any reason that throws RescheduledException
    2. retry is not null on the first attempt
    3. deallocate_networks_on_reschedule returns False
    4. network_api.cleanup_instance_network_on_host does nothing
      (e.g, neutronv2/api currently has a null implemnetation)

The side effect of not proper cleaning up the network is that VM would
be rescheduled to a different hypervisor with in-compatible network, causing
the VM lose connectivity

Part of the trigger for the issue is that the bridged_network is not compatible
among the candidate compute nodes on retry. The current proposed fix is to
detect the presence of immobile networks (bridge_network in this case), and if
true, call _cleanup_allocated_networks.

closes-bug: #1597596

Change-Id: Ida5a48d0e8612af639e6f4ce9fe590c798f4de51
Signed-off-by: aihuaedwardli <aihuaedwardli@yahoo.com>

commit_message:
VMware: Fix VMDK volume detach issue if the backing VM is unregistered

Currrently, if the backing VM is unregistered and registered back
in vCenter of an attached volume, the VMDK volume detach operation
fails. Because we are relying on the VM MOID present in the
connection_info, provided by cinder.
Due to ungistering the backing VM in vCenter, the MOID changes and the
ref created using that, will no longer be usable.

This patch addresses it by making the vCenter call explicitly by
name to get the "volume_ref".

Depends-on: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/344069/
Change-Id: Ie67465f9e6a72d3b2f8c082a17c1f5a759cd8431
closes-bug:1593742

commit_message:
Add output of the DB calls found by DatabasePoisonFixture

With the DatabasePoisonFixture, if a test derived from
test.NoDBTestCase makes a DB call, a warning is emitted indicating
that the test is setting internal oslo_db state that would conflict
with tests that are actually using the database.

This adds an additional warning output containing the offending
DB calls to help developers fix tests.

Change-Id: I6d4b6e4b34f4ac54fb1ee3e0bdcd4580b7884c49

commit_message:
Refactor to say auth_type instead of auth_plugin

auth_plugin has been deprecated, it has been renamed for auth_type.
Lets tidy up the code because of that.

Co-Authored-By: Sarafraj Singh <sarafraj.singh@intel.com>

Change-Id: I0d903ecb6207237797756bf1d30c6e51e43ec52b
Related-Bug: #1571839

commit_message:
Add cluster driver to Hyper-V

Adds implementation for the HyperVClusterDriver
in nova.

Change-Id: Ifdcbfa8b4282c73dad66abbb9f3b46df74f0d510
Co-Authored-By: Claudiu Belu <cbelu@cloudbasesolutions.com>
Implements-blueprint: hyper-v-cluster
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/33/301233/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2016 Cloudbase Solutions Srl # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """A Hyper-V Cluster Nova Compute driver.""" from nova.virt.hyperv.cluster import clusterops from nova.virt.hyperv.cluster import livemigrationops from nova.virt.hyperv import driver class HyperVClusterDriver(driver.HyperVDriver): def __init__(self, virtapi): super(HyperVClusterDriver, self).__init__(virtapi) self._clops = clusterops.ClusterOps() self._livemigrationops = livemigrationops.ClusterLiveMigrationOps() self._clops.start_failover_listener_daemon() def spawn(self, context, instance, image_meta, injected_files, admin_password, network_info=None, block_device_info=None): super(HyperVClusterDriver, self).spawn( context, instance, image_meta, injected_files, admin_password, network_info, block_device_info) self._clops.add_to_cluster(instance) def destroy(self, context, instance, network_info, block_device_info=None, destroy_disks=True, migrate_data=None): self._clops.remove_from_cluster(instance) super(HyperVClusterDriver, self).destroy( context, instance, network_info, block_device_info, destroy_disks, migrate_data) def post_live_migration_at_destination(self, context, instance, network_info, block_migration=False, block_device_info=None): self._clops.post_migration(instance) super(HyperVClusterDriver, self).post_live_migration_at_destination( context, instance, network_info, block_migration, block_device_info)

subject: libvirt/driver: direct boot with part table inject
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-15 18:30:29.000000000', 'files': ['nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/997e5b980f95ab3cb8dc329b41998c422c2cbc11', 'message': 'libvirt/driver: direct boot with part table inject

See bug #1290455 for full bug description.

Cirros test VM image on AArch64 comes with a partition table.
Also, on AArch64, direct kernel boot is currently recommended in
favor of using AAVMF on some platforms with buggy interrupt
controllers, leading to this limitation beng triggered.

Our proposal is to test the presence of a partition table inside
the disk image by checking the <root> kernel argument.

If <root> matches "/dev/.d.([1-9]+)", we are dealing with a part.

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1290455

Change-Id: I80a1e36c2ec2afd83c3bbb77c65c52fa029e8c09
Closes-Bug: #1290455
Signed-off-by: Alexandru Avadanii <Alexandru.Avadanii@enea.com>
Signed-off-by: Stanislaw Kardach <stanislaw.kardach@caviumnetworks.com>
'}]
commit_message:
libvirt/driver: direct boot with part table inject

See bug #1290455 for full bug description.

Cirros test VM image on AArch64 comes with a partition table.
Also, on AArch64, direct kernel boot is currently recommended in
favor of using AAVMF on some platforms with buggy interrupt
controllers, leading to this limitation beng triggered.

Our proposal is to test the presence of a partition table inside
the disk image by checking the <root> kernel argument.

If <root> matches "/dev/.d.([1-9]+)", we are dealing with a part.

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1290455

Change-Id: I80a1e36c2ec2afd83c3bbb77c65c52fa029e8c09
Closes-Bug: #1290455
Signed-off-by: Alexandru Avadanii <Alexandru.Avadanii@enea.com>
Signed-off-by: Stanislaw Kardach <stanislaw.kardach@caviumnetworks.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/40/330140/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import re image_meta = objects.ImageMeta.from_instance(instance) # FIXME(armband): https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1290455 # Support direct kernel boot with a partition table inside disk image: # pass target_partition when root kernel arg points to a partition # (instead of the whole disk). has_partition_table = re.search("root=/dev/.d.([1-9]+)", str(image_meta.properties.get("os_command_line"))) if not instance.kernel_id or has_partition_table:

commit_message:
Allow "revert_resize" to recover error instance after resize/migrate

When resize/migrate instance, if error occurs on source compute
node, instance state can rollback to active currently.

But if error occurs in "finish_resize" function on destination
compute node, the instance state would not rollback to active.

This patch is to rollback instance state from error to active when
resize or migrate action failed on destination compute node..

Closes-Bug:#1396003

Change-Id: I75e7e17b882f7b25847f61168df0d8632286b1d7

subject: Correct InstanceEvent debug messages
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-02-17 22:33:00.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/d400711d7202f13d678c8abe3b2f7e665d9f331f', 'message': "Correct InstanceEvent debug messages

Instance events can be sent to a compute host while it is not
currently running. When the compute manager is then started it
receives the events and attempts to handle them.  In this scenario
there will not be any waiters for the event since the manager was
just started.  The current code was sending a debug message saying
the event was received after event processing was cancelled because
it was incorrectly checking 'if not self._events:' which would be
True if self._events is either None or {}.  With None meaning
all events have been cancelled an no further events will be
handled.  This is the shutdown case.  When self._events is {},
it just means there are no waiters for the event.

This changeset adds a check for 'if self._event is None' and
sends the appropriate message only after events have been
cancelled.

Change-Id: Ia73f9a9740aa794697f3d7464eb59a6207fac61a
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-07-20 15:49:20.000000000', 'files': ['nova/tests/unit/compute/test_compute_mgr.py', 'nova/compute/manager.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/e9aa5a8024b578ba4be06340c3c09f8f261cb55e', 'message': "Correct InstanceEvent debug messages

True if self._events is either None or {}.  With None meaning

handled.  This is the shutdown case.  When self._events is {},

This changeset adds a check for 'if self._event is None' and
sends the appropriate message only after events have been
cancelled.

Change-Id: Ia73f9a9740aa794697f3d7464eb59a6207fac61a
"}]
commit_message:
Correct InstanceEvent debug messages

Instance events can be sent to a compute host while it is not
currently running. When the compute manager is then started it
receives the events and attempts to handle them.  In this scenario
there will not be any waiters for the event since the manager was
just started.  The current code was sending a debug message saying
the event was received after event processing was cancelled because
it was incorrectly checking 'if not self._events:' which would be
True if self._events is either None or {}.  With None meaning
all events have been cancelled an no further events will be
handled.  This is the shutdown case.  When self._events is {},
it just means there are no waiters for the event.

This changeset adds a check for 'if self._event is None' and
sends the appropriate message only after events have been
cancelled.

Change-Id: Ia73f9a9740aa794697f3d7464eb59a6207fac61a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/53/281553/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if self._events is None: LOG.debug('Unexpected attempt to pop events during shutdown', instance=instance) return None
deleted_lines: LOG.debug('Unexpected attempt to pop events during shutdown', instance=instance)

commit_message:
Make sure image metadata is retained after evacuation

Example:
    boot vm-test with image that has metadata qemu-guest-agent=yes
    evacuate vm-test to test-node
    nova evacuate vm-test test-node --on-shared-storage
    post instance evacuation, the image metadata is retained

    check libvirt xml

    <channel type='unix'>
      <source mode='bind' path='/var/lib/libvirt/qemu/org.qemu.
      guest_agent.0.instance-0000006d.sock'/>
      <target type='virtio' name='org.qemu.guest_agent.0' state=
      'connected'/>
      <alias name='channel0'/>
      <address type='virtio-serial' controller='0' bus='0'
      port='1'/>
    </channel>

recheck no bug

Fixes bug 1562681

Change-Id: Id74c81fae0022f2fe1c0938c7f68a53a75c37ca8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/19/308719/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

Change ignored exception in Ironic virt driver

During unprovisioning if Ironic node is already in a deprovisioned
state we should ignore InvalidStateRequested.
Ironic code reference:
https://github.com/openstack/ironic/blob/master/ironic/conductor/manager.py#L595-L615

subject: Data corrupt when attaching/detaching encrypted NFS volumes
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-15 06:53:48.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/103548a345d0bc0979b835fabef44d25568c4761', 'message': "Data corrupt when attaching/detaching encrypted NFS volumes

When attaching a NFS volume, Nova returns the real path in connection_info['data']['device_path'].
When a NFS volume is encrypted, Nova creates a decrypted device, and let above
device_path refer to the decrypted device. As a result, the original real path in NFS is corrupted.

This patch is to add a local symbolic path which refer to real path in NFS share folder, and return
the symbolic path in connection_info.

When attaching encryptors, Nova makes the symbolic path refer to decrypted device, and doesn't
destroy real file in NFS share folder.

commit_message:
Data corrupt when attaching/detaching encrypted NFS volumes

When attaching a NFS volume, Nova returns the real file path in
connection_info['data']['device_path']. When a NFS volume is encrypted,
Nova creates a decrypted device, and let above device_path refer to the
decrypted device. As a result, the original real data file in NFS is
corrupted.

When above volume is detached, the data file in NFS is lost and data
is lost.

This patch is to add a local symbolic path which refer to real file
in NFS share folder, and return the symbolic path in connection_info.

When attaching encryptors, Nova makes the symbolic path refer to
decrypted device, and doesn't destroy real file in NFS share folder.

Change-Id: I6d2ce5e638d713eb12e5cde2e91e17df1c7263e2
Closes-bug: #1511255

commit_message:
Build timeouts task filters deleting instances

The periodic task _check_instance_build_time sets instance
to error state on build timeout.Add a filter for deleting
instances so that there vm_state is not set to error.Also
provide a test case to validate that deleting instances are
ignored.

Change-Id: I0a4790cab7f83bbd464b1c5f75043d7f467cc707
Closes-Bug: #1501556

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-24 03:24:49.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/ff4603afb6918a3149671be893bc5b494c77ea50', 'message': 'Fixed ImageNotReady when running Rally snapshot_server scenario

Rally scenario snapshot_server may fail occasionally at nova boot.
nova complains about image not ready when Rally tries to boot
a new instance with the snapshot after it waits the snapshot to
become ACTIVE.

When create a snapshot for an instance, VMware driver will create
a temporary VM, then export the root disk to Glance. The temporary
VM and the snapshot will be deleted when the image upload is done,
and the image will set to ACTIVE.

The ACTIVE status of an image is considered to be ready to go to
the next operation to boot a new instance from the image in Rally.

However, exception may be thrown during the cleanup operations.
nova-compute will try to delete the image in case of error.
The image status will be set to "deleting" when it happens.

In the mean time, when Rally drives nova to create a new instance
for the image, nova-api will check whether the image status is
"ACTIVE" but it may just have been set to "deleting" which causes
the boot operation to fail.

This commit will omit exceptions during the cleanup to prevent
the image status from changing once the upload is done.

Change-Id: Ia47a477b1f24d462d9c4e7085bdf187ab1f5b3ad
Closes-Bug: 1487950

commit_message:
VMware: Omit exceptions during snapshot cleanup

Rally scenario snapshot_server may fail occasionally at nova boot.
nova complains about image not ready when Rally tries to boot
a new instance with the snapshot after it waits the snapshot to
become ACTIVE.

When create a snapshot for an instance, VMware driver will create
a temporary VM, then export the root disk to Glance. The temporary
VM and the snapshot will be deleted when the image upload is done,
and the image will set to ACTIVE.

The ACTIVE status of an image is considered to be ready to go to
the next operation to boot a new instance from the image in Rally.

However, exception may be thrown during the cleanup operations.
nova-compute will try to delete the image in case of error.
The image status will be set to "deleting" when it happens.

In the mean time, when Rally drives nova to create a new instance
for the image, nova-api will check whether the image status is
"ACTIVE" but it may just have been set to "deleting" which causes
the boot operation to fail.

This commit will omit exceptions during the cleanup to prevent
the image status from changing once the upload is done.

Change-Id: Ia47a477b1f24d462d9c4e7085bdf187ab1f5b3ad
Closes-Bug: 1487950

commit_message:
Translate power state strings with dict for nodes.set_power_state().

Nova Ironic driver will call ironicclient to set the power state of an ironic
node. But the power state strings ironicclient could pass are different from
those defined in ironic_states. So we need to translate the ironic power
states to the strings required by ironicclient.

The original code made the translation hard coded in reboot()/power_on/()power_off(),
which did not use constants defined in ironic_states.py. This patch uses a dict
to improve the translation.

Change-Id: I6bd80479613791c24a7096f66d8be528cb2c7167
Implements: blueprint soft-reboot-poweroff
Related-to: blueprint enhance-power-interface-for-soft-reboot-and-nmi
Co-Authored-By: Tang Chen <chen.tang@easystack.cn>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/84/248584/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Nova Ironic driver will call ironicclient to set the power state of an ironic # node. But the power state strings ironicclient could pass are different from # those defined in ironic_states. So we need to translate the ironic power # states to the strings required by ironicclient. See the help of command # "ironic node-set-power-state". _POWER_STATE_TRANSLATE = { ironic_states.POWER_ON: 'on', ironic_states.POWER_OFF: 'off', ironic_states.REBOOT: 'reboot', } self.ironicclient.call("node.set_power_state", node.uuid, _POWER_STATE_TRANSLATE[ironic_states.REBOOT]) self.ironicclient, instance, ironic_states.REBOOT) self.ironicclient.call("node.set_power_state", node.uuid, _POWER_STATE_TRANSLATE[ironic_states.POWER_OFF]) self.ironicclient, instance, ironic_states.POWER_OFF) self.ironicclient.call("node.set_power_state", node.uuid, _POWER_STATE_TRANSLATE[ironic_states.POWER_ON]) self.ironicclient, instance, ironic_states.POWER_ON)
deleted_lines: self.ironicclient.call("node.set_power_state", node.uuid, 'reboot') self.ironicclient, instance, 'reboot') self.ironicclient.call("node.set_power_state", node.uuid, 'off') self.ironicclient, instance, 'power off') self.ironicclient.call("node.set_power_state", node.uuid, 'on') self.ironicclient, instance, 'power on')

commit_message:
Fix instance delete stuck in deleting task_state

During instance deletion if rabbitmq-server crashes
after setting instance task_state to 'DELETING'. That
instance will get deleted only on nova-compute restart.

Added method to delete instances stuck in 'DELETING'
task_state without restarting nova compute service on
config reload.

DocImpact: This adds a new CONF option
'delete_instance_stuck_in_deleting_interval' to calculate
timeout, which in-turn is used to decide whether instance is
actually stuck in deleting task_state or the task_state is
set during normal delete request which is in-progress.

Change-Id: I879c442cd42349495db09237c8f28d693bb4c8c7
Closes-Bug: #1543511
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/91/294491/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: cfg.IntOpt('delete_instance_stuck_in_deleting_interval', default=3600, help='Interval in seconds for deleting instances stuck ' 'in deleting task_state. Set to -1 to disable. ' 'Seeting this to 0 will run at default rate.',), self._delete_instance_stuck_in_deleting_task_state(context, instance) def _delete_instance_stuck_in_deleting_task_state(self, context, instance): LOG.info(_LI('Service started deleting the instance during ' 'the previous run, but did not finish. Restarting' ' the deletion now.'), instance=instance) instance.obj_load_attr('metadata') instance.obj_load_attr('system_metadata') bdms = objects.BlockDeviceMappingList.get_by_instance_uuid( context, instance.uuid) project_id, user_id = objects.quotas.ids_from_instance( context, instance) quotas = self._create_reservations(context, instance, project_id, user_id) self._delete_instance(context, instance, bdms, quotas) @periodic_task.periodic_task( spacing=CONF.delete_instance_stuck_in_deleting_interval) def _cleanup_instances_stuck_in_deleting_task_state(self, context): filters = {'task_state': task_states.DELETING, 'host': self.host} attrs = ['info_cache', 'metadata'] instances_in_deleting = objects.InstanceList.get_by_filters( context, filters, expected_attrs=attrs, use_slave=True) timeout = CONF.delete_instance_stuck_in_deleting_interval / 6 for instance in instances_in_deleting: if timeutils.is_older_than(instance.updated_at, timeout): try: self._delete_instance_stuck_in_deleting_task_state( context, instance) except Exception: msg = _LE('Periodic delete failed to complete ' 'instance deletion.') LOG.exception(msg, instance=instance) self._set_instance_obj_error_state(context, instance)
deleted_lines: LOG.info(_LI('Service started deleting the instance during ' 'the previous run, but did not finish. Restarting' ' the deletion now.'), instance=instance) instance.obj_load_attr('metadata') instance.obj_load_attr('system_metadata') bdms = objects.BlockDeviceMappingList.get_by_instance_uuid( context, instance.uuid) project_id, user_id = objects.quotas.ids_from_instance( context, instance) quotas = self._create_reservations(context, instance, project_id, user_id) self._delete_instance(context, instance, bdms, quotas)

commit_message:
Prevent use filter(lambda ...) to meet python2,3

In python3 [1], if we need filter on python3, replace
filter(lambda obj: test(obj), data) with:
[obj for obj in data if test(obj)]. This patch introduces
a hacking rule to prevent using filter in future likes:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/362014/

Change-Id: Ia1a4dd4d3915ce5fd0c3bce371ffaafdfea3056e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/62/369862/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - [N353] Python 3: do not use filter.

commit_message:
Add memory metric monitor

This patch adds a new monitor for the Nova metrics framework. This new
monitor collects memory-related information.

Change-Id: Ib0f857e972ee67b403268c561656b832c94b7e76
Partially-Implements: blueprint host-memory-metrics

commit_message:
Add get_host_memory_stats virt driver API

This patch adds the get_host_memory_stats virt driver API, which will
in turn be used to collect memory-related stats by the to-be-created
memory metric monitor. This patch also updates the fake virt driver
to return some static data for purposes of testing and the like.

Change-Id: I9c94ad0cfd4be91746a2909505f69e78b7267a55
Partially-Implements: blueprint host-memory-metrics
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/38/288838/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _check_host_memory_status_fields(self, host_memory_status): self.assertIn('total', host_memory_status) self.assertIn('used', host_memory_status) @catch_notimplementederror def test_get_host_memory_stats(self): host_memory_status = self.connection.get_host_memory_stats() self._check_host_memory_status_fields(host_memory_status) @catch_notimplementederror

commit_message:
Add option to disable local disks in flavors [1/3]

This new feature adds the possibility to define a flavor,
that does not create ephemeral disks on the hypervisor;
A new boolean field 'local_disks' is added to flavors.
If local_disks=False, users are "forced" to create
a bootable volume to launch an instance from that flavor.

This commit is the database/object related part of the
implementation.

Change-Id: I99bbf9b29100813609a62aa925600bc6bd4ba9c0
Implements: blueprint flavor-root-disk-none
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/01/280301/13 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #-1 means root disk is disabled by intention self.assertInvalidInput('flavor1', 64, 1, -2)

subject: Change disable_live_snapshot workaround
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-09-20 15:35:48.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/5aa1f71b51c3961c30fc2b7c35c32d65c40c0f65', 'message': 'Change disable_live_snapshot workaround

We are running in the gate with libvirt > 1.3 now, lets see if we can
do live_snapshot by default again.

Change-Id: I35fd40c2cf1d89c6ae23db2de5e20b3082f0e795
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-09-20 18:50:14.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/762717d918828182c99a9b6c8500efc2de73ec19', 'message': 'Change disable_live_snapshot workaround

We are running in the gate with libvirt > 1.3 now, lets see if we can
do live_snapshot by default again.

Start fixing unit tests, which are finely tuned around the alternative
snapshot path, and break if this default is changed.

commit_message:
Change disable_live_snapshot workaround

We are running in the gate with libvirt > 1.3 now, lets see if we can
do live_snapshot by default again.

The snapshot unit tests need to be effectively pinned to the non live
path, as they are tuned for the non live path, and the live path
requires different mocks.

Change-Id: I35fd40c2cf1d89c6ae23db2de5e20b3082f0e795

commit_message:
Reschedule boot when attach volume fails

Instance boots that fail during host side volume attachment are not
rescheduled to other hosts.  Host side volume attachment consists
of the get_volume_connector call to the virt driver and the
initialize_connection call to Cinder.  Either of these calls could
fail on host specific issues and could succeed if the instance were
rescheduled to another host.

The fix is to throw a new volume attachment exception if either of
these attachment methods fail and let this exception trigger a
reschedule instead of a BuildAbortException as is currently done.

Change-Id: I9600e2e2c3cb17228f5e44cf2699c44c18306aa4
Closes-Bug: #1488111

commit_message:
Optimize the function to use the right parameter

Function get_disk_size() has parameter but not use it,
it is strange for us.As rbd backend use rbd_name as
base image.So pass rbd_name to the get_disk_size() function.

Change-Id: I511780e2d72dbd491e28ad6e25a4d33e7e4c3bae
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/95/323095/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Change LockServerController response codes

Change LockServerController lock and unlock response
codes from 202 to 204 as more appropriate since they
dont return any content.

Change-Id: Iccdd8e5ce0f736a72b521a867f5c938a5860eb4d
Depends-on: I2c081878c18f2905a9509cfdbc84deec32127154
